_	"Amin Karim is a Clinical Associate Professor at the Baylor College of Medicine in the Department of Medicine. His primary research interests and areas of expertise centre around cardiology, hospital cardiology services, after-hours care, and the delivery of healthcare, particularly in emergency situations such as floods. Karim has at least one notable publication to his name, titled ""Answering the Call,"" which was published in the Methodist Debakey Cardiovascular Journal in 2019. As a part of the Baylor College of Medicine community, Karim's contributions facilitate collaborative and mentorship opportunities in cardiology and healthcare delivery research."

_	Bert O'Malley is a Distinguished Service Professor at Baylor College of Medicine, holding positions in multiple departments including Molecular & Cellular Biology, Medicine, Neuroscience, and Obstetrics & Gynecology. His primary research interest lies in the field of nuclear receptors and their coactivators, systems metabolism, and the role they play in health and disease. With a particular focus on hormonal regulation and receptor interaction in breast cancer and endometriosis progression, O'Malley has been the principal investigator for numerous NIH funded projects, contributing significantly to our understanding of these conditions. His numerous publications demonstrate his extensive expertise in the field, with the most recent ones dealing with topics like transcriptional coactivation of NRF2 signaling, the biological function of Treg and Th17 cells, and the development of SRC-3 inhibitors. This wealth of research experience and knowledge makes him suitable for research collaboration or mentorship roles, particularly in the areas of endocrinology, molecular biology, and reproductive biology.

_	"Amanda Padilla is an Assistant Professor at Baylor College of Medicine, in the Department of Pediatrics. Her main research interests, as derived from her publications, include pediatrics, and specifically cases dealing with anemia. A notable publication of hers is ""Case 2: Acute Onset and Worsening of Anemia in a 3-year-old Boy"" which was published in the Pediatric Review in May 2019. Her work has demonstrated expertise in condition-specific pediatrics and academic research. The research interests and professional profile of Amanda Padilla make her an ideal candidate for potential collaborations or mentorship in the field of pediatrics, specifically anemia in children."

_	"Heather Farthing is an Assistant Professor at the Baylor College of Medicine, specifically in the Department of Emergency Medicine. Her main research interests and areas of expertise include social stigma, truth disclosure, health knowledge, attitudes, practice, and HIV/AIDS prevention techniques such as pre-exposure prophylaxis. Farthing has made significant contributions through numerous publications in reputable journals including ""Perfusion"", ""J Am Coll Emerg Physicians Open"", and ""AIDS Behav"". More specifically, Farthing has published studies exploring the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on patient transport and remote extracorporeal membrane oxygenation cannulation, a case of torsion of the undescended testes, and the illness narratives of children living with HIV in Ghana. Her work has broader implications for improving practices and behaviors surrounding HIV/AIDS and other health conditions. Over the years, she has shown a consistent commitment to her research, producing works as recently as 2022. In her work, she has collaborated with others and"

_	Lavannya Pandit is an Associate Professor in the Department of Medicine at Baylor College of Medicine. She holds a Doctorate of Medicine from the University of Texas-Southwestern, an M.S. in Clinical Investigation from Baylor College of Medicine, and has a research background focused on Pulmonary/Critical Care Medicine. Her research primarily targets the role of TWIK 2 potassium channels in the development of pulmonary hypertension, a topic she has received NIH funding for from 2014 to 2017. Throughout her career, she has made several significant contributions to understanding and treating severe COVID-19 infection, including notable publications focusing on the association of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase Deficiency with COVID-19 outcomes, the benefits of Remdesivir in treating severely infected patients, and the efficacy of monoclonal antibody therapies. She has also been part of studies investigating the efficacy and safety of novel treatments for hospitalized patients with COVID-19.

_	"Sagar Dhamne is an Adjunct Associate Professor at the Baylor College of Medicine, specializing in Pathology and Immunology. His research interests are focused on breast neoplasms, kidney neoplasms, Sarcoma, Clear Cell, Tumor biomarkers, and Estrogen Receptors. Dhamne has contributed to the field through multiple publications, notable among which are studies on ""Breast Cancer Prevention"" and ""Understanding Steroid Hormone Receptors in Ductal Carcinoma"". His expertise in pathology has led to valuable insights into various disease processes, especially in relation to neoplasms and hormone receptor roles. Notable co-author partnerships include collaborations with professionals such as Neda Zarrin-Khameh and Hugo Villanueva. His work alongside other notable researchers in the Department of Pathology & Immunology attests to his suitability for collaborations or mentorship within this field."

_	Pablo Lohmann Gandini-Bill is an accomplished Assistant Professor at Baylor College of Medicine in the Department of Pediatrics located in Houston, Texas. His main areas of research and expertise revolve around pediatrics and neonatal-perinatal medicine. Dr. Gandini has contributed significantly to numerous medical research publications focused primarily on areas such as spontaneous breathing and early repair in neonates, predictors of mortality in very low birth weight neonates, and risk factors for preoperative pneumothorax in neonates, among others. He received his training from prestigious institutions such as Baylor College of Medicine and University of Colorado Health Sciences Center, further enhancing his credibility in the medical field. He is also renowned for his work associated with fetoscopic endoluminal tracheal occlusion in congenital diaphragmatic hernia and has extensive experience in managing medical and surgical needs of infants with extreme prematurity conditions. Dr. Gandini’s dedication to his work is evident from his significant contributions, making him a suitable
